transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** Sarah (Corporate Representative, iRobot)

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Kelly (Customer) ---

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Hi Kelly, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Sarah, and I'm with the customer experience team at iRobot. We really appreciate you sharing your candid feedback with us online, and we're committed to understanding our customers' experiences, both good and bad. So, we'd like to dive a little deeper into your experience with the Roomba 694.

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** (Sighs) No problem, Sarah. I’m happy to talk about it, although I think my review pretty much covered everything. I just hope this conversation actually leads to some improvements.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Absolutely, Kelly, that's precisely why we're having this chat. Your detailed feedback is invaluable for us. To start, could you tell me a bit more about what initially prompted you to consider purchasing a robot vacuum, and specifically the Roomba 694 model? What were you hoping it would achieve for you?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Well, I’m a store manager, so I’m on my feet all day, and lately, I’ve been dealing with some pretty significant mobility issues. Nothing permanent, I hope, but it just makes everyday tasks like vacuuming incredibly difficult and painful. My home is a single-story, not huge, but it has a mix of low-pile carpet and linoleum. I thought, "This is it! A smart device that can just keep things tidy without me having to push a heavy vacuum around." I really needed something to lighten the load, you know? And the 694, it was… uh, it was presented as a reliable, entry-level option with Wi-Fi connectivity, which sounded perfect for scheduling.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I completely understand that desire for convenience, especially with your work and mobility concerns. You mentioned the Wi-Fi connectivity was a major issue. Could you walk me through that initial setup process? What happened, and how did it affect your ability to use the Roomba?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Oh, that was an absolute nightmare. I consider myself pretty tech-savvy, I manage a whole POS system at work, but this thing… it just refused to connect. My home network is stable, I’ve got other smart devices – a smart TV, my thermostat – they all connect fine. But the Roomba? It felt like a personal vendetta. I tried over and over, following the app instructions, rebooting my router, rebooting the Roomba itself. Eventually, I had to call my son over – he’s much younger, better with these things – and even he struggled for a good hour or so. We finally got it linked up.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** And once it was connected, did it maintain that connection, or did you continue to experience issues?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** No, it was incredibly unreliable. It would frequently disconnect. And then, you're back to square one, trying to re-pair it, which, again, was a frustrating process. It made using the app for scheduling cleanings or even just checking its status completely useless. What’s the point of a "smart" feature if it's not actually smart enough to stay connected? I basically gave up on using the app altogether after a few weeks of this. I just had to hit the button on the vacuum and hope for the best.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's incredibly frustrating, particularly when you’re relying on those smart features to help with your mobility. Let's move on to the actual cleaning performance. In your review, you described its navigation as "utterly baffling" and a "chaotic dance." Could you elaborate on what you observed during a cleaning cycle? What did it typically do, and what areas seemed to be missed?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** (Chuckles sardonically) Chaotic dance is truly the best way to put it. It didn't seem to have any logical pattern. It would just… bump around. It’d hit a chair leg, back up, spin, hit it again, maybe move two feet, then hit something else. I’d watch it spend like ten minutes just circling in one small corner of my living room, then abruptly take off across the room, leaving huge sections completely untouched. I'd come home after it had run, and I'd see these clean strips where it had clearly been, but then visible dust and crumbs right next to them. It wasn't cleaning *my* home; it was just going on a random adventure.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** So, it sounds like it wasn't effectively covering the entire area, even in your modest-sized home. You also mentioned it frequently got stuck. Given that your home is generally neat and uncluttered, what kinds of obstacles seemed to trip it up most often?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Oh, everything! (Frustrated laugh) I really made an effort to declutter before I even bought it, anticipating this might be an issue. But it would get stuck under the lowest lip of a cabinet in the kitchen – it’s not even that low! – or, you know those small decorative rugs with a little fringe? It would inevitably get tangled in the fringe and just stop, beeping pathetically. Even just wedging itself against a chair leg, not really getting tangled, just… stuck. And this wasn't once in a while, Sarah. It was every single time it ran. Often multiple times during one supposed cleaning cycle.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Wow, that frequent intervention must have been incredibly disruptive. How did you typically discover it was stuck, and what did you have to do to resolve it?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Usually, the app would notify me, but like I said, the connectivity was so bad, sometimes it wouldn’t. Other times, I’d just hear the beeping. And then I’d have to go find it. With my mobility issues, that’s not a quick or easy task. I’d have to bend down, sometimes kneel, to pull it out from under something or untangle it. What was supposed to *save* me effort actually ended up demanding *more* attention and physical exertion than if I’d just used a lightweight stick vacuum myself. It completely defeated the purpose.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's a critical point – it increased your workload rather than reducing it. Beyond getting stuck, you also highlighted issues with battery life and maintenance. Could you tell me about those experiences?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** The battery was dismal. Even on the rare occasion it *didn't* get stuck and managed to run for, say, twenty or thirty minutes without intervention, it would almost always run out of power before finishing even half of my small home. And then what? It would just die in place, sometimes in the middle of the carpet, and I’d have to manually carry its surprisingly heavy body back to the charging dock. Or it would embark on this long, futile quest to find its home base, only to die a few feet away. It was ridiculous. And the dustbin? Filled up incredibly quickly, like within ten minutes. My home isn't *that* dirty. It felt like it was picking up very little besides surface dust. And the brushes… oh my goodness. Trying to clean those was a whole other ordeal. My hair, my dog’s hair – it would just get tangled and wrapped around them. It required this fiddly, awkward process to remove them and then spend five minutes trying to de-tangle everything.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** It sounds like the entire user experience, from connectivity to daily operation and maintenance, was consistently challenging. Considering everything you've shared, how did this product ultimately impact your daily life and your overall stress levels, especially given your initial hopes for it?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** It was a source of immense stress and disappointment, honestly. I was so hopeful, you know? I really wanted this to work, to make my life easier. Instead, it became just another chore, another thing that needed my constant attention and troubleshooting. Every time I heard that pathetic error beep, my heart would just sink because I knew I’d have to go rescue it again. It wasn't just a failed product; it was a daily reminder of something that was supposed to help me but just added to my difficulties.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's a really powerful way to put it, Kelly. If you were speaking directly to our product development team, knowing everything you know now, what would be your top one or two suggestions for improving the Roomba 694, or perhaps a future entry-level model?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Okay, top two. First, the navigation. It needs a complete overhaul. It can’t just randomly wander. It needs to map the room, learn the layout, and clean systematically. If it spent ten minutes in one corner, it shouldn't leave the rest of the room untouched. And it absolutely needs to be able to finish a cleaning cycle in a modest-sized home without dying. Longer battery life, or the ability to accurately return to its base and recharge, and then *continue* cleaning, not just give up. And second, the getting stuck issue. Seriously, test these things in actual homes, with common furniture and small rugs. It needs to be smarter about detecting obstacles and avoiding getting wedged. That constant beeping and intervention completely negates any benefit.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Those are very clear and actionable suggestions, Kelly, and I've noted them down. Thinking about the price point of the Roomba 694, which is typically in the low to mid hundreds, did you feel that the product offered good value for money based on your experience?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** (Scoffs) Good value? No, absolutely not. I mean, I paid for a convenience device that offered anything *but* convenience. It was a waste of money, frankly. I’ve probably spent more time troubleshooting it than it ever spent actually cleaning. If I had known what I know now, I would have just saved that money and put it towards a more expensive model, or honestly, just hired someone to vacuum once a week. It certainly didn't deliver on the promise of its price.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Given your extremely frustrating experience, what would it take for you to consider trying an iRobot product again in the future, or perhaps a competitor's robot vacuum? What features or guarantees would be essential for you?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that’s a tough one. For me to even consider another robot vacuum, whether it's an iRobot or a competitor, it would have to guarantee vastly improved navigation – I mean, truly systematic cleaning. It needs reliable connectivity, so the app is actually usable for scheduling and status checks. And critically, it absolutely cannot get stuck every five minutes. If it gets stuck once or twice a month, fine. But daily? No way. And it needs to complete its cleaning without dying and needing to be carried back. Basically, it needs to work *autonomously* as advertised. If it requires my constant attention, it’s not a solution for my mobility issues; it’s just another problem. I'd need to see independent, glowing reviews specifically addressing these points, not just marketing fluff. Maybe some sort of stronger money-back guarantee too.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's very fair, Kelly. Autonomy and reliability seem to be the absolute core requirements for you. Finally, Kelly, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being "extremely dissatisfied" and 10 being "extremely satisfied," what would be your overall satisfaction rating for the iRobot Roomba 694 based on your entire experience?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** (Pauses, a long sigh) You know, after everything, the stress, the disappointment, the complete failure to deliver on its basic promise… I’d have to give it a 1. A definite 1.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Thank you for that honest rating, Kelly. We really appreciate you sharing such comprehensive and detailed feedback with us today. Your insights are incredibly valuable, and we'll be sharing this directly with our product and engineering teams. We truly apologize that the Roomba 694 did not meet your needs or expectations, and that it caused you so much frustration.

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** I appreciate you listening, Sarah. I really do hope this feedback helps your company improve things for other customers.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s our goal, Kelly. Thank you again for your time. Have a good rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** You too. ---
